question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
Consider a random walk that has transition matrix:

\begin{align*}P=\begin{bmatrix}
1/4  &  1/4  &  1/4\\
3/4  &  3/4  &  1/4\\
0  &  0  &  1/2
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

If the walker starts in state 3 then find the probability that he will
be in state 3 again after two steps.
sols:
The probability of being at the $i^{th}$ state at the $n^{th}$ time step
is given by the $i^{th}$ entry in the vector $\mathbf{p}^{(n)}$, where

\begin{align*}\mathbf{p}^{(n)} = P^{n}\mathbf{p}^{(0)}\end{align*} and $\mathbf{p}^{(0)}$ is
the initial distribution of probability.

In this case, $\mathbf{p}^{(0)} = [0,0,1]^{T}$ since we are starting in
the third state with probability 1. We want to compute the $3^{rd}$
entry of $\mathbf{p}^{(2)}$,

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{p}^{(2)} = P^{2}\mathbf{p}^{(0)}
&= \begin{bmatrix}
1/4  &  1/4  &  1/4\\
3/4  &  3/4  &  1/4\\
0  &  0  &  1/2
\end{bmatrix}^{2}\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
1/4  &  1/4  &  1/4\\
3/4  &  3/4  &  1/2\\
0  &  0  &  1/4
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
1/4\\
1/2\\
{\color{blue}1/4}\end{bmatrix}\end{align*} Therefore, the probability of being in the third state at
the second step is 1/4.
